intro: Thladiantha nudiflora var. bracteata, commonly known as the naked-flower thladiantha, is a flowering plant native to the southern United States. It is a member of the Solanaceae family, which includes nightshades, and is characterized by its simple, often hairy stems. The plant produces small, yellowish-green flowers that are typically clustered in the leaf axils, and it bears red, fleshy berries that are edible when ripe. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in woodlands and along stream banks.
